content: The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2012" is the short title of this Act. It outlines the terms of grazing permits and leases. Section 402 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 is amended to extend the time period from "ten years" to "20 years" for grazing allotments, permits, or leases. Additionally, it includes provisions related to the initial environmental analysis under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The amendment extends the time period for grazing allotments, permits, or leases from "ten years" to "20 years" under Section 402 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. It also includes a provision stating that the initial environmental analysis under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 has not been completed for a grazing allotment, permit, or lease. SEC. 405 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 amends the renewal, transfer, and reissuance process for grazing permits and leases. In SEC. 405 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, definitions for "current grazing management" and "Secretary concerned" are provided. The former refers to grazing in accordance with existing permits or leases, while the latter pertains to the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System land and the Secretary of the Interior for other lands. The term 'Secretary concerned' in SEC. 405 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 refers to the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System land and the Secretary of the Interior for other lands. Grazing permits or leases issued by these Secretaries may be renewed, transferred, reissued, or pending processing. The Secretary of the Interior handles land under their jurisdiction, while grazing permits issued by the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System land can be renewed, transferred, or reissued under specific sections of relevant acts. National Forest System land grazing permits can be renewed, transferred, or reissued under specific sections of relevant acts, with terms and conditions continuing in effect. National Forest System land grazing permits can be renewed, transferred, or reissued under specific sections of relevant acts, with terms and conditions continuing in effect until processing is completed by the Secretary concerned. The renewed, transferred, or reissued permit or lease remains valid until processing is completed by the Secretary concerned, in compliance with applicable laws. Cancellation, suspension, or modification may occur in accordance with the law. The renewed, transferred, or reissued permit or lease can be cancelled, suspended, or modified in accordance with applicable law. The Secretary concerned may renew or reissue the permit or lease for a term of 20 years after completion of processing. Compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 is at the discretion of the Secretary concerned. The Secretary concerned may renew or reissue a grazing permit or lease for 20 years after processing, and may categorically exclude the need for an environmental assessment if the grazing management continues as is and monitoring shows no significant issues. The Secretary may be exempt from preparing an environmental assessment or impact statement if the grazing management continues as is, meets objectives, or aligns with policy. The Secretary may be exempt from environmental assessments if grazing management meets objectives or aligns with policy. The Secretary determines priority and timing for completing environmental analyses. The Secretary has the discretion to prioritize and determine timing for completing environmental analyses for grazing allotments, permits, or leases based on environmental significance and available funding. NEPA exemptions apply to certain activities such as crossing and trailing authorizations for domestic animals. The National Environmental Policy Act exemptions include crossing and trailing authorizations for domestic livestock and transfer of grazing preference. Amendments to the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 are made to prioritize environmental analyses for grazing allotments, permits, or leases based on significance and funding availability.
